evg_transcriptome_pipe update picard

HPC has made changes so a different module and method of calling picard is necessary. It should work...

gff3_merge --mergeLiftoff

Skips valid_ORFs=0 features from consideration since they're likely to be spurious and/or simply give bad ORFs that aren't useful

New merging logic which (I believe) fixes some issues with the original one. Getting statistics at the end is also a lot quicker since this method retains information more intelligently

evg_transcriptome_pipe better trim skipping

Previously, we just assumed the input reads were pre-trimmed if we wanted to skip trimmomatic. But sometimes we want to resume a job where trimmomatic has already been performed. This should do that in theory. I need to test it on the HPC now.

evg_pipe add Trans-ABySS and fix concat

With Trans-ABySS added, I'm happy with the coverage of existing assemblers. The concat script needs to be updated to reflect its inclusion of this and rnaSPAdes.

transcriptome_pipe add spades assembler

SPAdes seems to be a good assembler in terms of avoiding misassembly from benchmarks, and in the absence of genome-guided assembly it makes sense to add in new methods which might give better results
Remove deprecated sh files for transcriptome pipe

evg_transcriptome_pipe GG-dependent minsize for cull

If it's de novo only, we should reduce the minimum size so as to pick up short transcripts better. Genome-guided assembly can leave that to the GG methods which should be more accurate than de novo with short things
evg_transcriptome_pipe fix bug with oases script

evg_transcriptome_pipe use bbmerge, not picard for GG

STAR mapping can take a really long time, even with the speed up of subsetting. The changes here mean that we no longer need to run STAR mapping if we aren't making a GG assembly.

evg_transcriptome_pipe new subset and star

STAR script is a little different (with bug fixes) and subsetting will now avoid using CD-HIT (waaaaay too slow) in favour of just getting the longest transcripts from the file. Will test to see if STAR can do this quick enough without subsetting the reads files

fasta_extractSubset.py overhaul, add longest

Script has been modernised to some degree. Parsing of FA/FQ files is much better now. New sampling mechanism "longest" allows for the longest N sequences to be output

evg_transcriptome_pipe cd-hit for subset

The Trinity dn assembly can come out too big. It makes STAR demand a huge amount of memory, and it'll just be unnecessarily slow.
Also fixed bugs with file locations for subset reads

EGF2 seg change and final cov cutoff

Seg is still having issues with spurious dropping of otherwise good sequences that just happen to consist primarily of domains that are somewhat low-complexity/repetitive. Otherwise, the final covcutoff has been put in because we're probably annotating a lot of sequences that simply aren't similar to the original exonerate query and therefore can't reliably be considered a toxin candidate.

EGF2 validation and seg filter changes

Also fixed some bugs and stuff, yknow how it be

EGF2 testing new culling steps

As it turns out, the original EGF was doing a good enough job of emulating GGF. I still think it could be better if I truly built it from the ground up again, but I aint got time for that. I just need it to work.

Helps to remove spurious LCR alignments leading to crappy gmap hits.

EGF stop codon extension modification

Program might produce bad models through taking a good partial alignment and extending through crap just to reach a stop codon, potentially within an intron region where the real continuation occurs downstream in another exon. Requires testing to be incorporated.

GGF compare_novels changes

Same idea as the EGF changes. Proven to work in EGF, should slot in without issues here. Unsure how much impact this will have on the outcome, probably might discover another dozen or so genes in a normal sized genome, but that's still good.
EGF fix for behaviour change

EGF compare_novels_store_rejects changes

I encountered a situation that I can only assume indicates some unintended behaviour in this code. It is possible, in a case with 3 genes, for 2 genes to be non-overlapping and compatible, and for 1 of these said genes to be overruled by a 3rd one which does not overrule the other gene. Essentially, the "poison" gene removes another gene before itself being removed, thus resulting in only 1 gene making it through rather than the "poisoned" gene and the other one which would make for 2 genes. I need to test this in practice to see what changes it brings about, however.

Bug fix

Simple error, easy fix.

Behaviour changes for improved model detection

Program behaviour was modified on the basis of testing with a real data set. Currently it seems to work well, but I need to run one more major test to be confident of this.

gff3_index update for this one too

Forgot this program uses the function. Reveals a bit of a problem with my current understanding of how to share code between different programs, but it's working for me currently (future me will probably look at this statement with a frown)

Attributes can be retrieved/removed

Attribute values/keys can be used as markers for items which should be retrieved or removed

gff3_index updates

Better indexing for subfeatures and improved layout for shortcuts and other storage structures for values of different types

Bug fix for seqType argument

I hadn't used this script with anything but 'both' specified, so I didn't encounter this problem earlier. oops.

Behaviour changes and fixes

Bug fixes are added for handling cds_to_prot() results. Unused function removed. SignalP calling function is modified to result in less overall signalP calls since, even with its own temporary directory, the program trips over itself for unknown reasons. Sequence can be shortened a bit more to find a good start site. More outputs are provided to facilitate manual inspection of results.

Major updates w/ bug fixes

Some minor fixes to program behaviour but mostly involves really obvious fixes (I lacked the -gm and -cd arguments from testing), important bug fixes, and updates so signalP can be run multiple times without each instance tripping over each other. Program should be ready to use.

Improved detection behaviour; more output

Some rearrangements and removal of program behaviour lets us capture more gene models. Additional output (sigpDrops and covDrops) lets the user manually check "failed" alignments to see why, and whether it's possible to "rescue" a real gene using some manual effort. All up, the program is basically ready for use.

WIP: Refining prediction behaviour

I've got some more testing data which is letting me modify the program behaviour to maximise its performance. It's still a WIP but I've managed to double the amount of good predictions made in my test set of input sequences, and now I just need to validate that rejected sequences were correctly rejected.

Working version

EGF appears to be working reasonably well now, but I haven't tested it on the "real" dataset just yet. Parameters and other behaviours may change upon performing this.

WIP: Candidate curation

Lots of new things being added and experimented with. Currently a bug occurring which will need to wait til tomorrow.

Add translation table option

Lets us handle annotations for organellar genomes etc.

GFF3 input option

Sometimes you want to feed the output of this program back into it, but you can't do that without allowing GFF3 input. Fixed that now.

Complete mtdna_gff2_order

Program seems to work and the functions within might be useful for other purposes.

WIP: about to change index_contig_reorder

Code is starting to become functional, but it's clear that there are limitations to this. MITOS2 doesn't provide ideal annotations, and the start position of the sequence can influence the annotation's correctness. Additionally, it's crappy GFF2 formatting means you can't tell which intron is actually the start of the gene. Frustrating.

secondaryValues shortcut

Extra shortcut for indexing.

Fix to previous commit

Silly mistake

primaryValues index for shortcutting

Although geneValues is a helpful shortcut for iterating through primary features annotated as 'gene', sometimes we need to iterate through all primary features including 'ncRNA_gene' or other types. This shortcut helps to do this more simply.

WIP: index to lines function

The gff3_index_denovo_lines() function may be quite helpful for future efforts. I'm saving a version here since I'm likely removing the contig sorting from the function since it's not necessary for this specific function (although it is needed for later in this specific program).
Extended GGF description
Create LICENSE.md

Alternative to gffcompare

gffcompare doesn't seem to work well with S. cerevisiae's annotation. I'm unsure the reasons why, but mikado works better overall. It throws up a few exceptions which don't appear to halt program execution which is slightly concerning, but it's the better of the two options from what I can see.

Make CDS building code a function

This lets us copy it into other programs easily.

Handling of gene features without CDS

Although I don't agree with GFF3 formatting where 'gene' features can contain subfeatures that are not coding, these files exist and this code needs to be able to handle them.

Working version for novel analysis

The results are pretty rough around the edges, but it does help to give some insight into what the "novel" genes identified by gffcompare are likely to be.

WIP: Fixes for non-CDS gene features

Code needs updates to handle gene features that contain subfeatures that are not mRNAs.

Reject or replace functionality

Added in what was inevitably going to be required. The interaction of mode and behaviour can result in unintended consequences, hence the warning in the usage text.

Behaviour refinement

Defaults updated to be more sensible, and additional curation checks are in place to prevent spurious and low-quality results from occurring.

Formatting issue fix

another oops

Sequence ID consistency change

PASA and EGF presents sequence IDs with format like {contig_id}.{model_name}.{model_number} so this change will add the {contig_id}. bit so we have a consistent naming scheme (I also think having the contig ID in the sequence name is kind of helpful for things like the annotation table).

Fix for handling EGF

EGF has a slightly different ID schema than GGF, so I've needed to modify gff3_merge to accomodate this.

Header comment fix

PASA presents mRNAs in the header comments, so we should do the same

knownHeadComments change

# EXONERATE_GENE_FIND is a valid comment that we expect to handle in these programs now

Working version of EGF, partner

to GGF. This program borrows most of its code from GGF but removes some of the "strictness" from model curation and allows single-exon models through. Program appears to work properly now but more testing might reveal the odd bug.

Check subfeature attributes for ret/rem

Sorting for GFF3 variant compatibility

Some GFF3's order - strand feature CDS/exons from 1->inf, whereas others will order them from inf->1. This raises problems with our original approach, so we need to sort these consistently to produce correct results. For example, Esembl's GFF3's go from 1->inf whereas TAIR and PASA order it inf->1.

GFF3 parsing overhaul and major update

Code now operates using new GFF3 parsing system. Also added ability to derive proteins from the GFF3 entries directly using phasing information.

Fix to merged comments

Was causing issues with the new gff3_index parsing system. From what I can tell, this code should now be working 100% properly - the new parsing system helps to ensure that because it's a little bit strict.

GGF indexing update for non-gene lines

Not a behaviour change. This just lets us parse GFF3 files with non-gene lines in them. Currently, these are limited to lineType's of rRNA or tRNA.

Final splice rules filtering modification

I did some actual testing with this before pushing the commit for once. I'm happy with the results this produces. Because we have a bad splice remover later in the program, having length take priority of splice rules should be fine, and it so we don't accept a fragment of a gene (which is in a region with only perfet splices) over the larger gene (which has a few non-canonical splices but is still good).

Splice rules modification

10% was being too strict and allowing obviously worse models through. I'll trial 20% and see if this works appropriately without being too lax.

GGF behaviour change & merge info

GGF's behaviour was noticed to be a bit different after changing SSW handling, and for the worse in some cases (BUSCO scores reduced). I looked into the reason and found that my splice filtration system was killing a few genes that were obviously better than others due to their length being longer and including 1 noncanonical splice. Now, we only filter on splice sites if there is a large difference between the percentage values (in the 3 cases I observed, the % difference was about 5%, so 10% should be a safe cutoff).

GFF3 merge overhaul complete

Bringing GFF3 parsing changes over to gff3_merge. Also modified program significantly to work better in situations where we're separating mRNAs from genes/merging two very similar GFF3 files. Theoretically, this should work with all GFF3 files in a way that is robust and transparent... hopefully?

GFF3 parsing overhaul complete

Program produces identical output to the previous program (before considering the ssw change) while being able to parse, hopefully, any GFF3 you can throw at it. SSW was changed to handle the sequences as proteins correctly, which should result in a few extra good gene models being found when compared to before.

WIP major updating to GGF

GGF's code was too specific with how it parsed GFF3 files. I'm overhauling this so we can handle GFF3 files (hopefully) from just about any program that outputs GFF3 compliant files.

Disallow fragment transcripts becoming models

Extra stringency check reduced the number of models in Aulactinia by about 100 which seems reasonable. The check is quite simple, if the transcript doesn't end with a stop codon we ignore it. Previously, it was possible that we'd build a gene model that is quite likely to be fragmented. There is the possibility that the stop codon correction would naturally fix the model, but if an entire exon was missing from the tail of a transcript, our new model would be flawed.
Move to unused folder

Not good enough; shelving for now

The idea is still valid, but it's too difficult to effectively make the kind of fixes I was planning (i.e., automatic detection and fixing of merged gene models). In Aulactinia there's every chance I can fix about 100 gene models, but I am unable to be certain what he error rate of this program will be. Since it is affecting so few genes and I can't be sure about whether it's truly working well or not, I'm going to shelve it. I might still make a CDS location fixer especially since Actinia seems like it might need it, but I might just leave it as is. PASA should have done a good enough job (hopefully) and BUSCO scores are still reasonable even for the CDS extracted regions. Bit disappointing that this didn't work out, but it happens.

Ready for use

Made final changes to behaviour (validation occurs later now). Changed default parameters based on testing to be more strict - I recover about 1450 genes in Calliactis now. Made alignment pct parameter tunable on commandline. New output function resembles PASA's output - it should be OK to just insert this into the main annotation GFF3.

Probably final version

Everything seems to work well. On Calliactis I'm getting about as many models as I expected (~2000) and from a cursory manual inspection (can't inspect them all...) most things look good. I could theoretically be a bit stricter and cut down the number of models further to have even higher confidence, but I think what is currently there seems fine. Last bit of testing will be done on the other genomes to see if the number of models is within reason there, too.

I will definitely need to curate for transposons now, though.
New name to match its function

Multiple inputs, main loop finished, needs final checks

Script modified to accept multiple GFF3 files on the command line. This is so we can combine their outputs within the one script. The main loop is finished now, it works for handling most gene models well. One time an assert statement wasn't met, but when I re-ran it it worked. Bug in one of the modules? Unsure, but there is nothing random in my own code so I must assume that. There are a few scenarios that likely need specific curation checks to fix such as one scenario where there is a microintron that, when filled in, results in a single exon gene. Removing genes that solely consist of microexons should resolve this problem.

Almost done; changes to behaviour INC

Program is almost fully functional (I think). I'm changing certain parts of program behaviour to make things easier. Currently, absolutely no overlap with existing genes is allowed (even in the opposite orientation). This makes things much easier to handle. This version of the code allows "isoforms" to slip through. The next version will remove any overlaps whatsoever. This will come at a cost to true positives, but it should decrease false positives and it makes the code much easier to work with since I don't need to do any isoform clustering (which wouldn't be THAT difficult, it's just that I feel like the program has already gotten 10x more complex than I ever intended it to be...)

CDS extension includes stop; new output

CDS extension works for both orientations. Various tests and conditions exist that will be stripped out as I no longer think they are needed.

WIP: CDS Extension after alterations

Needs further testing; '-' orientation seems to work but I need to test '+' orientation too. After this, I need to modify other parts of the program to allow no stop codons, which we can then remedy using this extension module.

Coord fixing functionality

Capable of correcting problems with exons where the CDS does not start on the first exon indicated by GMAP. Next update should be to re-apply the CDS extension function in cases where we do alter the start/stop exon to capture the full ORF, and also to cull any models that turn into single exon genes.

Near complete version

This script is able to successfully find extra copies of genes that do not overlap existing gene models. Currently it needs manual curation to ensure that the model is accurate. I think the final touch would be to do this process automatically - this might involve checking splice borders (I don't mind alternative splite sites much personally if identity is high...). I need to do some manual checking to find cases where I disagree with the results, and that will help me to figure out what this automatic process would require.

Extend table with exon,intron details

Adds four new columns to the annotation table. These include 1) transcript and CDS lengths, 2) transcript and cds exon regions (gives coordinates from 1->len(sequence) with respect to whether it's a transcript or CDS), 3) exon support from transcripts (behaves similarly to gff3_statistics.py in the deGRIT repository), and 4) intron lengths. Combined, this information makes it easier to manually inspect sequences and make relevant judgements. Also - this marks the likely end to these annotation extension scripts. In the future I may decide to include more information in this table, or to bundle these scripts to automate the process, but the day I do that is not today.

Functioning gene model rescuer

There is currently an implementation of what I am referring to as a "gene model rescuer", whereby we don't solely require pre-established exon boundaries to perform correction but instead use more strict GMAP alignment gathering for genomic regions not covered by predicted gene models. I've validated this on (what should be) a massive gene model that lacks most of its internal exons due to indel errors. When correcting this sequence I'm able to add the internal exons back in manually and I end up with a smooth reading frame without error. Good proof of concept, but I need to make sure this always works, and then try to make the code faster.

Adding new functionality

WIP: Almost finished

Script is in the final polishing phase where I'm trying to find odd scenarios and see if the script handles these naturally or if I need to add rules for these.

WIP: Simplifying program

From testing with an unnecessarily more complex version of this program, I realised that it was quite powerful and could be simplified to work in a more general manner when allowing non-exact matches at the borders of exons. This naturally corrected all of the scenarios I was trying to handle (gene model fragmentation across an exon, within-exon fragmentation) and should also naturally handle most occurrences of gene model fragmentation across an intron. It's possible I'll generalise the program even more to just work directly with the GMAP alignments - it might be a bit risky, but I think with some safe guards it'll help us find even more gene models.

WIP: Working with some minor issue

Currently I can't figure out how to get the RNAseq "patch" for all regions that don't have exact matches. Exact matches make it easy, but inexact matches mean that we can't reliably get the start bit. Because of this, I'm thinking of changing the code's function a little to use MUSCLE alignment of the "patch" against the joining region to 1) find the borders of the RNAseq patch reliably, and 2) identify the locations of the indels to just remove these indels rather than full-scale "patching" the RNAseq region into the genome, since this might introduce variants from other individuals into the genome. While this isn't bad imo (the original human genome was a mosaic) it's probably easier to convince others that this program isn't doing anything "weird" if I keep its interaction with the genome sequence to an absolute minimum.

WIP: Adding module to handle inexact overlaps

Before I more fully integrate this function I'm saving a backup. This function will act to allow regions without exact matching 5' start position alignments to be used to patch the sequence.

WIP: Fragmented genes handled

Currently the program works to patch fragmented genes together using RNAseq editing of the exon sequence. Still need to make a downstream program to perform the genome edits and modify the annotation GFF3 file (might be tricky...). Program ideally should be modified to handle exon breakages without too much difficulty.

WIP: Final stages

My goal is for this script to "patch" a genome sequence using RNAseq transcripts to correct indels using sequence that is biologically accurate. You can theoretically "fix" gene models by introducing N's or deleting bases to offset frameshifts, but it can be difficult to figure out where the correct location is to place these modifications. Using transcripts from the species itself, these errors should be minimised even if the result is a bit of a mosaic of individuals.

Assess evidence for gene models

Combines evidence from multiple sources to find gene models that are likely to be false. From my testing, even with a wide range of evidence, it's hard to be confident that the identified gene models are actually false, even for sequences with >90% LCR since many have seemingly good BLAST hits e.g., to histone acetyltransferases, and so using a too-strict E-value cut-off will result in the removal of genuine gene models as well. Thus, I likely won't be using this script but it might be useful for another purpose later.

Modify CDS regions of gff3 file

Helper script originally intended to find the starting frame of the CDS region and modify this in the file itself. Later on realised that doing this wouldn't properly represent the genomic information, so I decided to modify the gff3_to_fasta.py script. This script may be useful later, or might provide a foundation for reworking to be something else.
Extract lines from gff3

AA sequences from PASA comments

Changed script to derive the AA translations directly from the PASA comment lines. Translating the CDS resulted in nonsense for a small handful of genes that had 5' fragmentation, and the reading frame column of PASA doesn't seem to help overly much in finding these events.

Improvements to handle directories

File previously assumed everything was in the same (current) directory. I've fixed it so it can find the files where they actually are.

Script to curate repeat-masked gene models

Script combines data gathered regarding gene models largely encompassed by repeat-masked sequence and identifies gene models that should be removed from the final gene set.

Added seg results column

This information will be used in the final gene model curation.

Made script capable of producing nice table output

Makes manual annotation just that bit easier
Change to handle no ORF scenario

Calculate percentage of protein that is LCR

Helper script to manually curate the output gene models. From more hand-on manual inspection, most gene models that are overlapped by repeat masked sequence that I think should be removed from the final annotation have a high proportion of low complexity regions. This script, in tandem with the repeat masked proportion, should make it easier to automatically remove sequences which meet both criteria strongly, and to manually check sequences that fall into a 'borderline' region wherein I'm not sure if they should be given a chance to be considered genuine or discarded as a crappy gene model.

Find gene models that overlap masked regions

No softmasking information is provided during PASA gene model annotation (intentionally) which means I need to filter out some crappy gene models. Finding models which are overlapped by masked sequence is a useful way of narrowing down the list of potential crap models.

Distinguish higher support AUGUSTUS models

Script to change the identifier column in EVM-formatted gff3 files for AUGUSTUS predictions so as to allow more weight to be provided to sequences with more hint support.

Script to make new augustus output work with EVM

The newer AUGUSTUS version has different output than previous versions, and the scripts bundled with EVM hasn't updated alongside this. This script essentially makes AUGUSTUS' gtf output look similar to older versions so that the augustus_GFF3_to_EVM_GFF3.pl script can handle it properly.

Another helper script to deal with GMAP errors

Script removes lines from the BLAT gff3 file that contain hits to sequences that have been removed due to "problem sequence" errors. Reason this script was made is because BLAT was run on the whole transcriptomes prior to fixing this error with GMAP, and I don't want to re-run BLAT from scratch.

Helper script to run PASA

Error fixer script which will automatically iterate through gmap alignment phase of PASA to remove "problem sequences" which cause gmap error. The reason why these sequences cause error is unknown, but removal fixes the issue so I'll take what I can get.
